intro: Lycianthes bullata, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Central America and the Caribbean. It is a member of the Solanaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like tomatoes and peppers. The plant typically grows as an erect annual herb with hairy stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers are usually yellow or white, and it produces small, berry-like fruits that are toxic to humans but may be used in traditional medicine. The plant's botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
